title: Booting GNU/Linux on USB pendrive from Windows

forumNotes.author: Fabrice Eudes
forumNotes.content:
Hi all, I'm new here and I hope that my question hasn't been asked before as, I am probably stupid, but I haven't found any "search" button to explore previous posts. :wink: Aim : to be able to boot a usb live system from any computer I sit in front of, even when it isn't "friendly" ; let's say usb boot non active in a bios which is password protected. I wonder if this could be achieved with this setup ? * a usb pendrive with 2 partitions. * a small FAT32 (or FAT16 or FAT) at the beginning to make it accessible from a Windows OS. * another partition with a GNU/Linux-live OS, marked as bootable.
So that : * if the computer offers usb boot, I can boot directly onto my second partition. * if is doesn't, I let the host Windows OS boot, access the first partition and use stuff there to launch the OS on the second partition **without rebooting the hardware**.
I have two questions : * Can a computer boot on the second partition (marked as bootable) of a usb pendrive ? * Booting a GNU/Linux OS from within a started Windows OS has been doable in the past : one had to use LoadLin with a Win95/98/Me. But Win 2000/XP/+ are differents (see the link below) so I don't know if it still can be done ?
Of course, I have spent quite some time looking for information about this. For example, I found this page about [LoadLin/Grub4Dos](http://marc.herbert.free.fr/linux/win2linstall.html "External link"), but it was last updated in 2006 so I'd like more recent information and/or users feedback on this kind of setup. Thanks for any help ![:coffee:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/coffee.gif)

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
what you want isn't possible EXACTLY as you described it. There is no problem with multiple partitions on a USB stick, but you will need to have the USB stick "flipped" or use a filter driver (dummydisk.sys or cfa disk.sys) that will need to be installed on the "internal disk" NT OS. About Search, change the board view from (whatever is standard) i.e. Whitish to 911CD i.e. light bluish and you will find the Search page. Since it sucks anyway, you can use google like: ``` site:reboot.pro winkexec ``` and ``` site:reboot.pro PLoP ```
Both "PLop" and "Winkexec" being apps that may be of help in your goal, as well as "grub4dos" and "kexec-loader". Very basically you can use PLoP (by itself or together with a bootmanager, like grub4dos) to: * boot system "normally" * add an entry to your "normal" bootmanager bootloader, being it NTLDR/BOOT.INI or BOOTMGR/\\boot\\BCD or anyone else and copy to internal disk the (few) needed files. * from this entry boot grub4dos (to have more possibilities/features) than from it PLoP or PLoP directly * then from PLop hopefully boot from the USB * BUT a reboot (after you have added the grub4dos or PLoP) is needed.
![:coffee:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/coffee.gif) Wonko
